properties.description:
NANJING

CHINA

Nanjing was the capital of the Ming Dynasty. Zheng He set off from Nanjing after receiving an imperial edict to gather a fleet of ships in Taicang and go on a long voyage. The tomb of Zheng He was restored afterwards in Nanjing in 1985, and a museum was built next to it. There is also Nanjing Treasure Shipyard Relic Site Park and Zheng He Park in Nanjing in honour of Zheng He.

TAICANG

CHINA

Taicang, part of the city of Suzhou, is a city located south of the mouth of the Yangtze River. The city reached its heyday between 1271 and 1368. During the Ming Dynasty, the port of Liuhe in Taicang was the departure point for Zheng He's treasure ships.

QUANZHOU

CHINA

Quanzhou, located in the south of Fujian province, was a major port for Chinese foreign traders from the 11th to the 14th century. Quanzhou was the point of return and disembarkation for Zheng He's voyages. The seafaring technology was advanced; Zheng He visited Quanzhou to employ fleets of seafaring technicians, craftsmen, and interpreters.

CHAMPA

VIETNAM

From approximately the 2nd century AD until 1832, Champa was a collection of independent Cham polities that extended across the coast of what is today central and southern Vietnam. As the first stop on Zheng He's voyage to the West and an important node on the Maritime Silk Road, the Kingdom of Champa played an important role in the Maritime Silk Road due to its bountiful products and its favourable geographical location, thus reaping huge benefits.

SINGAPORE

SINGAPORE

Even though Zheng He’s fleets haven’t visited Singapore, all of their seven voyages have gone through the Singapore Strait. According to the Mao Kun Map, Zheng He's fleets once reached the southernmost point of the Malacca Strait and passed a huge stone that looks like a dragon's tooth, named Dragon's Tooth Gate.

HO CHI MINH

VIETNAM

Zheng He's fleet might not have visited Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City, the capital of Vietnam), but there are accounts of the rivers and ports to the south of the city in the Mao Kun Map.

MALDIVES

MALDIVES

The history of the Maldives is intertwined with the history of South Asia and the Indian Ocean. Chinese pottery buried in various locations in the Maldives also suggests direct or indirect trade links between China and the Maldives. Zheng He visited the Maldives at least twice in 1413 and 1431. Zheng He's records provide detailed information on Maldivian specialities and customs, among other details. These archives from China also tell us that in 1417, the Maldivian King Yusof sent an ambassador to visit the Emperor in Nanjing, the capital of China.

AYUTTHAYA

THAILAND

The Ayutthaya Kingdom existed from 1351 to 1767 in Siam, or present-day Thailand. There are three temples associated with Sam Po Kong (the name by which Zheng He is known there) in Thailand, where many Chinese characters are left. They were probably used for worship by Zheng He during his visits, which is circumstantial evidence that Zheng He listed Siam as a port of call during his 15th century explorations. A statue of him stands today in the city.

JAVA

INDONESIA

Java is the world's most populous island, constituting approximately 55% of the Indonesian population. Before Zheng He arrived in Java, Chinese merchants had already established settlements there. The porcelain and silk products carried by Zheng He's fleet became the most popular goods.

PALEMBANG

INDONESIA

Palembang is the capital city of the Indonesian province of South Sumatra. It was the capital of Srivijaya, a Buddhist kingdom that ruled much of the western Indonesian Archipelago and controlled many maritime trade routes, including the Strait of Malacca. Zheng He settled the vicious pirates, led by Chen Zuyi, and restored peace to the city.

MALACCA

MALAYSIA

Malacca is a state in Malaysia, next to the Strait of Malacca. In the 15th century, this was the midway point on the maritime crossing between China and the lands along the western rim of the Indian Ocean. Sailors from Zheng He’s fleets built homes and storehouses on the Straits of Malacca, and many of them chose to stay there. The Cheng Ho Cultural Museum, a museum about the life of Zheng He, was opened in Malacca in 2006.

SAMUDERA

INDONESIA

The Samudera Pasai Sultanate was a Muslim harbour kingdom on the north coast of Sumatra from the 13th to the 16th centuries. By the 13th century, the collapse of Srivijayan power drew foreign traders to harbours on the northern Sumatran shores of the Bay of Bengal, safe from the pirate lairs at the southern end of the Strait of Malacca. Northern Sumatra had a hinterland rich in gold and forest produce. It was accessible to all the merchants of the archipelago who wanted to meet ships from the Indian Ocean. For many centuries, Arab and Indian Muslims traded in Indonesia and China.

Ceylon

SRI LANKA

Sri Lanka, formerly known as Ceylon, lies in the Indian Ocean, southwest of the Bay of Bengal and southeast of the Arabian Sea. Sri Lanka's geographic location and deep harbours have made it of great strategic importance as a major trading hub. The trade in luxury goods and spices attracts traders from many countries.

LAMU

KENYA

Lamu Old Town is the oldest and best-preserved Swahili settlement in East Africa, retaining its traditional functions. There are some accounts that mention Chinese ships of Zheng He's fleet sinking near Lamu Island, where bits of Ming ceramic ware have surfaced in the past. Survivors are said to have settled in the island. However, the authenticity of this story is disputed.

GALLE

SRI LANKA

Galle is the provincial capital and largest city of the Southern Province, Sri Lanka. Galle was a prominent seaport in history. The Persians, Arabs, Greeks, Romans, Malays, Indians, and Chinese were doing business through Galle's port. In 1411, the Galle Trilingual Inscription, a stone tablet inscription in three languages: Chinese, Tamil, and Persian, was erected in Galle to commemorate the visit to Ceylon by Zheng He. It was found by an engineer, S. H. Thomlin, in 1911 in Galle.

COCHIN

INDIA

Kochi, formerly known as Cochin, is a major port city on the Malabar Coast of India. Kochi was an important spice trading centre on the west coast of India from the 14th century onwards, and maintained a trade network with Arab merchants from the pre-Islamic era. The earliest documented references to Kochi occur in books written by the Chinese voyager Ma Huan during his visit to Kochi in the 15th century as part of Zheng He's treasure fleet.

CALICUT

INDIA

Calicut (Kozhikode) is a city along the Malabar Coast in the state of Kerala in India. Zheng He stopped at Calicut on each voyage to rest and replenish his reserves. Ma Huan (the sailor of the fleet under Zheng He) lauds the city as a great emporium of trade frequented by merchants from around the world. Zheng He died at Calicut during this last voyage of 1433.

HORMUZ

IRAN

Hormuz is an Iranian island in the Persian Gulf. The 15th century was a significant period of growth in Indian Ocean trade, during which the farthest reaches of western and eastern Asia, the kingdom of Hormuz and Ming China, were linked together by trade routes, and each discovered the other's culture through commerce and communication. Contact between China and the Persian Gulf, which had flourished since the earliest years of the Ming Dynasty, was greatly enhanced by the seven voyages of Zheng He. Zheng He's first visit to Hormuz was around 1413. Zheng He visited Hormuz many times and brought many Chinese products like silken fabrics.

MUSCAT

OMAN

Muscat, the capital and most populated city in Oman, has been known since the early 1st century as an important trading port between the west and the east. Zheng Zheng visited here on his fourth voyage.

DHOFAR

OMAN

The Dhofar Governorate lies in Southern Oman, on the eastern border with Yemen. It was first visited by Zheng He's secondary fleet on his fourth voyage.

ADEN

YEMEN

Aden, the temporary capital of Yemen since 2015, is near the eastern approach to the Red Sea (the Gulf of Aden). The first visit by Zheng He's fleet was on his fourth voyage. According to the book Yingyai Shenglan by Ma Huan, who accompanied the imperial envoy, the Ming dynasty Yongle Emperor ordered envoy Li Xing and Zhou Man of Zheng He's fleet to visit the port of Aden in 1421.

JIDDAH

SAUDI ARABIA

Jiddah (Jeddah) is a city in the Hejaz region of Saudi Arabia and the country's commercial center. Jeddah is the principal gateway to Mecca. In 1432, Zheng He detached two ships to Aden, but tensions in Yemen forced them north to Jiddah, where they offloaded silk, porcelain, musk, and other goods.

MECCA

SAUDI ARABIA

The holy city of Mecca is in present-day Saudi Arabia. On the seventh voyage of Zheng He, seven men, including the minister Ma Huan, were sent to accompany a ship bound for Mecca. The seven men brought porcelain and other items to Mecca and returned with commodities and valuables, including giraffes, lions, and ostriches, that they had purchased. Mecca also sent ministers back to visit China.

CHITTAGONG

BANGLADESH

Chittagong, is the second-largest city in Bangladesh. Arab Muslim traders frequented Chittagong from the 9th century. In mediaeval times, Chittagong was a hub for maritime trade with China, Sumatra, the Maldives, Sri Lanka, the Middle East, and East Africa. It was notable for its trade in pearls, silk, muslin, rice, bullion, horses, and gunpowder. The port was also a major shipbuilding hub. Zheng He's treasure fleet anchored in Chittagong during imperial missions to the Sultanate of Bengal.

ZEILA

SOMALIA

Zeila is a historical port town in the western Awdal region of Somaliland. The Adal kingdom had its capital in the city. Through extensive trade with Abyssinia and Arabia, Adal attained its height of prosperity during the 14th century. It sold incense, myrrh, slaves, gold, silver, and camels, among many other commodities. Zeila had by then started to grow into a huge multicultural metropolis.It is likely that a fleet of Zheng He arrived here, as it is recorded in the Mao Kun Map.

MOGADISHU

SOMALIA

Mogadishu is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. The city has served as an important port, connecting with traders all around the Indian Ocean for millennia. Mogadishu has a long history, serving as the capital of the Sultanate of Mogadishu in the 9th–13th centuries, which for many centuries controlled the Indian Ocean gold trade, and eventually came under the Ajuran Empire in the 13th century, which was an important player in the mediaeval Silk Road maritime trade.

BARAAWE

SOMALIA

Barawa (Somali: Baraawe) is the capital of the South West State of Somalia. Facing the Indian Ocean, Barawa serves as the main port on the East African coast, and it was reached by the Zheng He fleet in the Ming Dynasty. The Chinese mariner Fei Xin characterised the people of Barawa as pure and honest from the experiences during the voyages.

MOMBASA

KENYA

Mombasa is a coastal city in southeastern Kenya along the Indian Ocean. Mombasa's location on the Indian Ocean made it a historical trading centre. Mombasa was an important centre for the trade in spices, gold, and ivory. Its trade links reach as far as India and China. Archaeologists have discovered Chinese porcelain in a Kenyan village; it is thought to have been brought by Zheng He during his 15th century ocean voyage.

MALINDI

KENYA

Malindi is a town on Malindi Bay at the mouth of the Sabaki River, lying on the Indian Ocean coast of Kenya. Once rivalled only by Mombasa for dominance in this part of East Africa, Malindi has traditionally been a port city. In the 15th century, the town was visited by the fleet of the Chinese explorer Zheng He. Malindi's ruler sent a personal envoy with a giraffe as a present to China on that fleet.

KOTA BHARU

MALAYSIA

Kota Bharu (KB) is a town in Malaysia. It is situated in the northeastern part of Peninsular Malaysia and lies near the mouth of the Kelantan River. Dataran Cheng Ho is an ancient memorial archway in Kota Bharu and an important landmark for the Chinese community in town. It was named after Zheng He, whose arrival in the country established great relations during the Ming Dynasty. The archway has Jawi, Rumi, and Chinese calligraphy etched upon it, which represents the cultural pluralism that exists in Kota Bharu.

KUANTAN

MALAYSIA

Kuantan is a city and the state capital of Pahang, Malaysia. It is located near the mouth of the Kuantan River. Kuantan Port is the largest port on the eastern coast of Malaysia. Zheng He passed Kuantan on their way to their base at Malacca for exploration in the Indian Oceans.

BANDA ACEH

INDONESIA

Banda Aceh, located on the island of Sumatra, is the capital and largest city in the province of Aceh, Indonesia. The Cakra Donya Bell, a gift from Zheng He to Pasai (Samudera), is now at the Museum Aceh in Banda Aceh.
